#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Chapter 10
#Text=Once a day I descend to the base of the cliff and hunt , and fill my stomach with water from a clear cold spring .
#Text=I have three gourds which I fill with water and take back to my cave against the long nights .
#Text=I have fashioned a spear and a bow and arrow , that I may conserve my ammunition , which is running low .
#Text=My clothes are worn to shreds .
#Text=Tomorrow I shall discard them for leopard-skins which I have tanned and sewn into a garment strong and warm .
#Text=It is cold up here .
#Text=I have a fire burning and I sit bent over it while I write ; but I am safe here .
#Text=No other living creature ventures to the chill summit of the barrier cliffs .
#Text=I am safe , and I am alone with my sorrows and my remembered joys -- but without hope .
#Text=It is said that hope springs eternal in the human breast ; but there is none in mine .
#Text=I am about done .
#Text=Presently I shall fold these pages and push them into my thermos bottle .
#Text=I shall cork it and screw the cap tight , and then I shall hurl it as far out into the sea as my strength will permit .

#Text=The wind is off-shore ; the tide is running out ; perhaps it will be carried into one of those numerous ocean-currents which sweep perpetually from pole to pole and from continent to continent , to be deposited at last upon some inhabited shore .
#Text=If fate is kind and this does happen , then , for God 's sake , come and get me !
#Text=It was a week ago that I wrote the preceding paragraph , which I thought would end the written record of my life upon Caprona .

#Text=I had paused to put a new point on my quill and stir the crude ink ( which I made by crushing a black variety of berry and mixing it with water ) before attaching my signature , when faintly from the valley far below came an unmistakable sound which brought me to my feet , trembling with excitement , to peer eagerly downward from my dizzy ledge .
#Text=How full of meaning that sound was to me you may guess when I tell you that it was the report of a firearm !

#Text=For a moment my gaze traversed the landscape beneath until it was caught and held by four figures near the base of the cliff -- a human figure held at bay by three hyaenodons , those ferocious and blood-thirsty wild dogs of the Eocene .
#Text=A fourth beast lay dead or dying near by .

#Text=I could n't be sure , looking down from above as I was ; but yet I trembled like a leaf in the intuitive belief that it was Lys , and my judgment served to confirm my wild desire , for whoever it was carried only a pistol , and thus had Lys been armed .
#Text=The first wave of sudden joy which surged through me was short-lived in the face of the swift-following conviction that the one who fought below was already doomed .

#Text=Luck and only luck it must have been which had permitted that first shot to lay low one of the savage creatures , for even such a heavy weapon as my pistol is entirely inadequate against even the lesser carnivora of Caspak .
#Text=In a moment the three would charge !
#Text=A futile shot would but tend more greatly to enrage the one it chanced to hit ; and then the three would drag down the little human figure and tear it to pieces .
#Text=And maybe it was Lys !
#Text=My heart stood still at the thought , but mind and muscle responded to the quick decision I was forced to make .
#Text=There was but a single hope -- a single chance -- and I took it .
#Text=I raised my rifle to my shoulder and took careful aim .
#Text=It was a long shot , a dangerous shot , for unless one is accustomed to it , shooting from a considerable altitude is most deceptive work .
#Text=There is , though , something about marksmanship which is quite beyond all scientific laws .
#Text=Upon no other theory can I explain my marksmanship of that moment .
#Text=Three times my rifle spoke -- three quick , short syllables of death .
#Text=I did not take conscious aim ; and yet at each report a beast crumpled in its tracks !

#Text=From my ledge to the base of the cliff is a matter of several thousand feet of dangerous climbing ; yet I venture to say that the first ape from whose loins my line has descended never could have equaled the speed with which I literally dropped down the face of that rugged escarpment .
#Text=The last two hundred feet is over a steep incline of loose rubble to the valley bottom , and I had just reached the top of this when there arose to my ears an agonized cry -- "Bowen ! Bowen !
